eda_steps.step_description: Analyzed the distribution of all four numerical features (sepal length, sepal width, petal length, petal width) across the three iris species using violin plots to understand class separability and feature discriminative power.
step_insights: Petal measurements (length and width) show much clearer separation between species compared to sepal measurements, making them more discriminative features for classification
Iris-setosa is clearly linearly separable from the other two species across all features, especially petal measurements, with non-overlapping distributions
Iris-versicolor and Iris-virginica show some overlap in their feature distributions, particularly in sepal measurements, making them harder to distinguish from each other

dataset_description: The Iris dataset contains 120 training samples with 4 numerical features (SepalLengthCm, SepalWidthCm, PetalLengthCm, PetalWidthCm) and 1 categorical target variable (Species). This is R.A. Fisher's famous 1936 dataset for taxonomic classification, featuring three balanced classes of iris flower species with 40 samples each.

columns.name: Id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each sample in the dataset
columns.additional_information: This column serves as a sample identifier and is not used for model training or evaluation.

columns.name: SepalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the sepal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature measuring the sepal length. Shows moderate discriminative power between species with some overlap.

columns.name: SepalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the sepal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature measuring the sepal width. Less discriminative than petal measurements but still provides useful information for classification.

columns.name: PetalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the petal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: Highly discriminative continuous numerical feature. Shows clear separation between species, especially distinguishing Iris-setosa from others.

columns.name: PetalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the petal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: The most discriminative feature showing excellent separation between all three species with minimal overlap.

columns.name: Species
columns.description: The target variable representing three iris flower species: Iris-setosa, Iris-versicolor, and Iris-virginica
columns.additional_information: Perfectly balanced categorical target with 40 samples per class. Iris-setosa appears to be linearly separable from the other two species.

eda_summary: The Iris dataset analysis reveals a well-structured classification problem with clear patterns. The dataset contains 120 balanced training samples across three species. Feature analysis shows that petal measurements (length and width) are significantly more discriminative than sepal measurements for species classification. Iris-setosa exhibits the most distinct feature distributions and appears linearly separable from the other species, while Iris-versicolor and Iris-virginica show overlapping distributions that will require more sophisticated classification approaches. The data is clean with no missing values and demonstrates the classic machine learning challenge where one class is easily separable while two classes require more nuanced differentiation.
